items.title: Cooking as a vegan is food safer. ğŸŒ±
items.content_html: Listening to an ATP episode from a couple years ago (because Iâ€™m currently listening to them all in order, but thatâ€™s a story for another time) and theyâ€™re talking about gift ideas. Marco Arment mentioned a kitchen thermometer and how you need it if you cooked and Iâ€™m reminded of how easy it is to cook and store food when you donâ€™t eat animals. Yâ€™all should try it. Food safety is basically a non issue.

items.title: Seriously, grind your own peppercorns. Youâ€™ll thank me.
items.content_html: I cook a lot and I always see â€œfresh black pepperâ€ as an ingredient and I go and grab my pre ground pepper. Well yesterday I bought peppercorns and holy shit. Why did I not try this sooner?! Also you donâ€™t need a pepper grinder if you have a mortar and pestle. (molcajete)

items.title: MarsEdit and Micro.blog
items.content_html:
Just listened to the Microcast from @manton and itâ€™s talking about MarsEdit by @danielpunkass how you can use both micro.blog and marsedit for the same things and I just thought it was interesting because I do that. Both amazing apps, though I use micro.blog more for browsing and quick posts and marsedit for longer stuff. I love that marsedit can pull in all your posts and edit them. Two amazing apps!

overcast.fm
items.content_text:

Both amazing apps, though I use micro.blog more for browsing and quick posts and marsedit for longer stuff. I love that marsedit can pull in all your posts and edit them. Two amazing apps!

items.title: Please give us usb-c on iPhone Apple!
items.content_html:
I was unsure if I really needed usb-c on my phone, but after using my wifeâ€™s iPad Pro more Iâ€™m realizing it is necessary. Okay, not necessary but I really would like to be able to charge both with the same cable and not have to unplug the cable from the charging brick and plug in the usb-c cable for the iPad. I am aware this is a classic â€œfirst world problemâ€, but thatâ€™s why I pay a bajillion dollars for these products.

As always @mjtsai has great quotes to support this.

mjtsai.com
items.content_text:

Okay, not necessary but I really would like to be able to charge both with the same cable and not have to unplug the cable from the charging brick and plug in the usb-c cable for the iPad. items.title: Messages needs mark as unread. Maybe.
items.content_html:
Mark as unread would be amazing, but this is why I enable message previews. I can read most of the message and leave it in an unread state. I was really excited when Face ID came around and I could make them hidden from view unless unlocked. And the unread status still works!

@gruber of course has more thoughts about it.

daringfireball.net
items.content_text:
Mark as unread would be amazing, but this is why I enable message previews. I can read most of the message and leave it in an unread state. I was really excited when Face ID came around and I could make them hidden from view unless unlocked. And the unread status still works!

items.title: tomato potato cauliflower pea and lentil curry for lunch
items.content_html: Aloo gobi mattar dal tamatar subzi. Potato, cauliflower, pea, lentil, and tomato curry. Adapted from the @veganricha recipe in her book page 87. I made this in the instant pot so had to adapt a little more but came out great. Also made some basmati rice and simmered mustard and cumin seed in oil and cooked that with the rice. Also pictured, roti cooked from dough I bought at the Indian grocery store.
items.content_text: Aloo gobi mattar dal tamatar subzi. Potato, cauliflower, pea, lentil, and tomato curry. Adapted from the @veganricha recipe in her book page 87. I made this in the instant pot so had to adapt a little more but came out great. Also made some basmati rice and simmered mustard and cumin seed in oil and cooked that with the rice. Also pictured, roti cooked from dough I bought at the Indian grocery store.

items.title: tostadas for dinner
items.content_html: Tostadas con frijoles y arroz Mexicano. I intended to make rolled tacos but made my beans too runny so we decided to air fry tortillas to make tostadas. They came out amazing! My wife also made a cheese sauce from @ohsheglows cookbook. As always the rice is @morenita.salazar.k recipe but Iâ€™ve adapted it over time to be vegan. The tostadas have beans, lettuce, tomatoes, pickled jalapeÃ±os, cheese sauce, salsa verde, @herdezmexico chipotle cremosa (holy shit this stuff is good), and cashew sour cream. These were next level.
items.content_text: Tostadas con frijoles y arroz Mexicano. I intended to make rolled tacos but made my beans too runny so we decided to air fry tortillas to make tostadas. They came out amazing! My wife also made a cheese sauce from @ohsheglows cookbook. As always the rice is @morenita.salazar.k recipe but Iâ€™ve adapted it over time to be vegan. The tostadas have beans, lettuce, tomatoes, pickled jalapeÃ±os, cheese sauce, salsa verde, @herdezmexico chipotle cremosa (holy shit this stuff is good), and cashew sour cream. These were next level.

items.title: What if we were using Mac OS 9 in 2021?
items.content_html:
Really cool video from Michael Feeney exploring what it would be like to use the technology of today with the limitations of yesterday. Itâ€™s amazing the skills that some people have. Amazingly well done.

Link to his site

the video

I used Mac OS 9 a few times when I was in the 4th or 5th grade, around 2002-2003. I can remember there being a couple iMac G3s in the back of my classroom. I wish I couldâ€™ve used it more.
items.content_text:

items.title: KFC plant based chicken nuggets are meh
items.content_html:
Tried the new Beyond Meat chicken nuggets from KFC because why not. Great breading, but unfortunately they were dense as hell. Another local restaurant, Sybergs, serves the beyond meat chicken tenders and while the breading isnâ€™t as good, they are moist and juicy. It was worth the try and Iâ€™d eat if I were stuck in the middle of nowhere, but itâ€™s about on par with the Burger King impossible whopper. Which is to say that non vegans seem to struggle with cooking non meat products.

What a shame because I love that there are more plant based options accessible to people who normally wouldnâ€™t seek that out. Iâ€™m hoping this is the beginning and not the end and there is only upside from here because we really shouldnâ€™t be raising animals for food. For many reasons.

items.title: Ticket to Ride Local multiplayer with DLC maps
items.content_html:
** tl;dr you choose the map on your phone, not on the game console. **

I purchased Ticket to Ride on my PlayStation 4 recently after playing the board game. I wanted to play the expansions as well and particularly in local mode so I could play with my wife. When we first purchased the DLC for the game, it was unclear to us how, if it all, to play the other maps. After spending an hour or so looking into it and reading online we couldnâ€™t find anything so we decided to try to get a refund on the DLC and just play the base game. So sad.

Through some sort of luck, we noticed something when playing the base game again after the refundâ€¦

A little background first.

When you start the game and choose local mode, the game asks you to install an app on your mobile device so that you can keep your cards to yourself. Makes sense. What we didnâ€™t realize is that the mobile interface is actually how you choose the maps! Â¡FantÃ¡stico! In other play modes you choose the map with the controller so we must have missed this earlier.

So like any reasonable person, we bought the DLC again and we were able to play the Europe version of the game! It was so much fun and more challenging than the US map. Highly recommend this game.

Footnote, thanks to Sony for giving us a refund. I also reached out to the company who made the game with the same question and they never got back to me after saying theyâ€™d reach out to the engineers. Amazing that no one had this info so hopefully this post will help some other poor soul who just wants to play the train game.

ğŸšğŸšŠğŸš‚ğŸš†ğŸš„ğŸš…ğŸšƒğŸš‡ğŸšğŸš‹ğŸšˆğŸ›¤ğŸš‰

items.title: Why does Xcode 13 not include an Info.plist for SwiftUI projects?
items.content_html:
I keep forgetting about this so maybe this will keep it in my mind.

Xcode 13 Missing Info.plist

Most important bit, go to project settings and click on info tab

The why

Projects created from several templates no longer require configuration files such as entitlements and Info.plist files. Configure common fields in the targetâ€™s Info tab, and build settings in the project editor. These files are added to the project when additional fields are used. (68254857)
items.content_text:
I keep forgetting about this so maybe this will keep it in my mind.

[Xcode 13 Missing Info.plist](https://useyourloaf.com/blog/xcode-13-missing-info.plist/)

### Most important bit, go to project settings and click on info tab

#### The why

> Projects created from several templates no longer require configuration files such as entitlements and Info.plist files. Configure common fields in the targetâ€™s Info tab, and build settings in the project editor. These files are added to the project when additional fields are used. (68254857)

items.title: Being a parent
items.content_html:
Now that my daughter is six months old I feel like I have a better grasp on what being a parent is like.

Itâ€™s so interesting how many different opinions there are. As my friend Bill once said, â€œNick, you like to live your life on hard modeâ€ and this is no different. Raising a baby without resorting to tv babysitting has been very interesting. Donâ€™t get me wrong, sometimes she sees the tv but we are careful to curtail it as often as it happens. Itâ€™s more effort to spend time with her and Iâ€™m so happy and fortunate that I have this opportunity.

Being a parent is the most amazing thing Iâ€™ve ever done and Iâ€™d do it again! If you have the means and desire, I would recommend it. Just make sure youâ€™re ready to change your life for them. Although I think once you meet your child youâ€™ll never have a thought that contradicts that love and care. Even in the challenging moments. Maybe Iâ€™m just crazy. Maybe Iâ€™m crazy in love. I donâ€™t know everything, but I do like being parent.

Important notes, Iâ€™m a reasonably well paid software engineer who gets to work from home and I make enough that my wife can afford to stay home with the baby. I recognize this is not the norm and many likely wouldnâ€™t want to live this way, but I do and I love it. I also recognize (or try to) my privilege

Also Iâ€™m aware that I write like a child and this is likely rambling nonsense, but I just wanted to write something about her.
items.content_text:
Now that my daughter is six months old I feel like I have a better grasp on what being a parent is like. 

Itâ€™s so interesting how many different opinions there are. As my friend Bill once said, â€œNick, you like to live your life on hard modeâ€ and this is no different. Raising a baby without resorting to tv babysitting has been very interesting. Donâ€™t get me wrong, sometimes she sees the tv but we are careful to curtail it as often as it happens. Itâ€™s more effort to spend time with her and Iâ€™m so happy and fortunate that I have this opportunity. 

Being a parent is the most amazing thing Iâ€™ve ever done and Iâ€™d do it again! If you have the means and desire, I would recommend it. Just make sure youâ€™re ready to change your life for them. Although I think once you meet your child youâ€™ll never have a thought that contradicts that love and care. Even in the challenging moments. Maybe Iâ€™m just crazy. Maybe Iâ€™m crazy in love. I donâ€™t know everything, but I do like being parent. 

Important notes, Iâ€™m a reasonably well paid software engineer who gets to work from home and I make enough that my wife can afford to stay home with the baby. I recognize this is not the norm and many likely wouldnâ€™t want to live this way, but I do and I love it. I also recognize (or try to) my privilege 

Also Iâ€™m aware that I write like a child and this is likely rambling nonsense, but I just wanted to write something about her.

items.title: My dad tried vegan meat and he liked it.
items.content_html:
Spent the weekend down at my dadâ€™s house. It was really nice to be out there and have them visit my daughter. It was also nice to bring down some vegan meats and have them try them. I was worried that theyâ€™d be like your typical person and shudder at the idea of it, but they tried the burgers and the sausages. I was surprised how much they enjoyed them. They even said they liked the beyond meat breakfast sausages more than they like regular sausage.

What an amazing weekend.

items.title: Pie pumpkins
items.content_html:
My wife has been making pumpkin pies lately from the little pie pumpkins you get at the grocery store. Normally weâ€™d buy canned, but thought fresh would be better. Iâ€™ve heard the large ones have no flavor really, but assumed the little ones would. And they do, but not as much as youâ€™d think.

I was especially curious why the canned pumpkin was so much darker. After doing a little research I learned that much of canned pumpkin is actually another squash called Dickinson pumpkin. Itâ€™s huge and kind of pale orange/yellow.

Maybe everyone knows this, but I was a little surprised. Iâ€™ll still continue to purchase pie pumpkins, but now I really want to try a Dickinson pumpkin.

I was especially curious why the canned pumpkin was so much darker. After doing a little research I learned that much of canned pumpkin is actually another squash called Dickinson pumpkin. Itâ€™s huge and kind of pale orange/yellow. 

Maybe everyone knows this, but I was a little surprised. Iâ€™ll still continue to purchase pie pumpkins, but now I really want to try a Dickinson pumpkin.

items.title: More places you can debug with a REPL
items.content_html:
Debugging by starting a REPL at a breakpoint is fun

This was a really interesting read about debugging using REPLs. Two more to add to the list are:

  • .NET using visual studioâ€™s immediate mode (I think thatâ€™s what itâ€™s called)
  • LLDB in Xcode (and probably outside of Xcode too).

I am a huge proponent of using the debugger statement in JavaScript. Debugging allows you to be able to see something at a moment in time and also inspect and execute other things. Itâ€™s like freezing time. I am generally not a fan of print statement debugging, but I recognize that sometimes you have to do what you have to do. ğŸ¤·ğŸ½â€â™‚ï¸
items.content_text:
[Debugging by starting a REPL at a breakpoint is fun](https://jvns.ca/blog/2021/09/16/debugging-in-a-repl-is-fun/)

This was a really interesting read about debugging using REPLs. Two more to add to the list are:

- .NET using visual studioâ€™s immediate mode (I think thatâ€™s what itâ€™s called)
- LLDB in Xcode (and probably outside of Xcode too).

I am a huge proponent of using the `debugger` statement in JavaScript. Debugging allows you to be able to see something at a moment in time and also inspect and execute other things. Itâ€™s like freezing time. I am generally not a fan of print statement debugging, but I recognize that sometimes you have to do what you have to do. ğŸ¤·ğŸ½â€â™‚ï¸

items.title: Hans Holbein the Younger
items.content_html:
I was on a bit of a Wikipedia spiral (I do this often) and wanted to share something I found. Itâ€™s a bit of a windy story, but hopefully you find it interesting and get the bug to read about history.

Â 

Yesterday I was reading about a town in England called Blackpool. I thought the name was interesting and was also curious what the â€˜poolâ€™ part meant. This led to me reading about bogs. They really are interesting.

I noticed an image of a bog in Ostfriesland. I know that Austriaâ€™s name in German is Ã–sterreich so I was curious what that word meant.

This led me to an image of a map of northern Germany and all the islands that are just off the coast.

This led me to opening Maps and poking around to see what else was there and I found that there are a ton of islands in that area of the North Sea around the border of Denmark and Germany. Looking at the map I found an island called Helgoland (Helgoland is the German spelling) and decided to look that up.

I read that this island was part of a bight. A word I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve encountered before. Looking up what the German bight was informative and led me to an image of the mouth of the Elbe with an island called Trischen visible. Really beautiful photo shot by Vincent van Zeijst.Â 

This image led me to the island which led me to the Bay of Meldorf which led me to the Battle of HemmingstedtÂ (Read about this!!!) which led me to the Kalmar Union which led me to the Hanseatic League which led me to this painting of Georg Giese by Hans Holbein the Younger. I was struck by how realistic this painting was. Reminds me of the Arnolfini Portrait by Jan van Eyck with itâ€™s extreme levels of detail.

Turns out Hans Holbein the Younger painted more than once!

Hereâ€™s another one I really liked. This is from 1534!Â 

There isnâ€™t much of a point to this post beyond I am very easily drawn to reading things on Wikipedia and this painter was incredibly talented.Â
items.content_text:
I was on a bit of a Wikipedia spiral (I do this often) and wanted to share something I found. Itâ€™s a bit of a windy story, but hopefully you find it interesting and get the bug to read about history.

Â 

Yesterday I was reading about a town in England called Blackpool. I thought the name was interesting and was also curious what the â€˜poolâ€™ part meant. This led to me reading about bogs. They really are interesting.

I noticed an image of a bog in Ostfriesland. I know that Austriaâ€™s name in German is Ã–sterreich so I was curious what that word meant.

This led me to an image of a map of northern Germany and all the islands that are just off the coast.

This led me to opening Maps and poking around to see what else was there and I found that there are a ton of islands in that area of the North Sea around the border of Denmark and Germany. Looking at the map I found an island called Helgoland (Helgoland is the German spelling) and decided to look that up.

I read that this island was part of a bight. A word I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve encountered before. Looking up what the German bight was informative and led me to an image of the mouth of the Elbe with an island called Trischen visible. Really beautiful photo shot by Vincent van Zeijst.Â 

This image led me to the island which led me to the Bay of Meldorf which led me to the Battle of HemmingstedtÂ (Read about this!!!) which led me to the Kalmar Union which led me to the Hanseatic League which led me to this painting of Georg Giese by Hans Holbein the Younger. I was struck by how realistic this painting was. Reminds me of the Arnolfini Portrait by Jan van Eyck with itâ€™s extreme levels of detail.

Turns out Hans Holbein the Younger painted more than once!

Hereâ€™s another one I really liked. This is from 1534!Â 

There isnâ€™t much of a point to this post beyond I am very easily drawn to reading things on Wikipedia and this painter was incredibly talented.Â

items.title: Never smell an infant's hand
items.content_html:
I was discussing with my wife whether we should bathe our baby last night.
I did a quick smell test and she smelled fine.
My wife said that her hands are filthy and sheâ€™d need a bath.
I said how filthy could they be, she canâ€™t even grab anything.
I was so wrong.
I was so so so so wrong.
But damn is she cute.
Moral of the story, donâ€™t smell an infantâ€™s hands.
They are filthy.
Though they did smell nice after a good scrubbing.Â

items.title: Every Programmer Is Not A Terminal User
items.content_html:
Iâ€™m always surprised that every programmer isnâ€™t a skilled terminal user. Perhaps itâ€™s because I got into programming after finally being able to purchase a MacBook, but having no idea what to do with it, I searched for â€œterminal hacksâ€ online and the rest is history.

I very much prefer to use the terminal for lots of tool things like git and basic Unix stuff. I do use a text editor though. Occasionally Iâ€™ll use vim but Iâ€™m not a magician.

Iâ€™ve seen many of my coworkers reach for a graphical git client and for some reason this surprises me over and over. Iâ€™m not shaming anyone. Just observing.

I wonder if they are surprised when they see me typing away on that black screen, chaining stuff together?

Iâ€™ve seen many of my coworkers reach for a graphical git client and for some reason this surprises me over and over. Iâ€™m not shaming anyone. Just observing.

items.title: Working with my brother on his website
items.content_html:
Iâ€™ve been working with my brother on his photography website for a few years and itâ€™s changed a lot over time.Â 

My first iteration was to take all the photos he sent me and make a basic website that displays them, using static html and css.

The next thing I tried was to store them in Firebase and then sort of dynamically pull in the images and import them into the same structure.

Then I learned about react.js and decided that I could try that out and build up his site. That was a pretty interesting experience and I learned a lot.

Unfortunately all of that took a lot of time and required me to basically build a CMS on my own. While I could probably do that, I realized over time that I didnâ€™t want to and furthermore couldnâ€™t devote the time to give him what he wanted. So I made the tough, ğŸ˜‚, decision to make him a SquareSpace website.

Iâ€™ve been listening to ads for them in podcasts for years and finally decided it was worth it. Why should I keep him from updating his stuff because I wasnâ€™t feeling the dev process. For the last 4 weekends, Iâ€™ve helped him work on the site and I have to say that itâ€™s a great experience.

Itâ€™s still the early stages, but Iâ€™m glad I had this journey. I learned a lot of web stuff that has made me a better developer and Iâ€™ve also learned when to be pragmatic. Iâ€™m glad I can help him get his stuff out there and I can still provide technical assistance.Â

My first iteration was to take all the photos he sent me and make a basic website that displays them, using static html and css.

The next thing I tried was to store them in Firebase and then sort of dynamically pull in the images and import them into the same structure.

Then I learned about react.js and decided that I could try that out and build up his site. That was a pretty interesting experience and I learned a lot.

Unfortunately all of that took a lot of time and required me to basically build a CMS on my own. While I could probably do that, I realized over time that I didnâ€™t want to and furthermore couldnâ€™t devote the time to give him what he wanted. So I made the tough, ğŸ˜‚, decision to make him a SquareSpace website.

Iâ€™ve been listening to ads for them in podcasts for years and finally decided it was worth it. Why should I keep him from updating his stuff because I wasnâ€™t feeling the dev process. For the last 4 weekends, Iâ€™ve helped him work on the site and I have to say that itâ€™s a great experience.

Itâ€™s still the early stages, but Iâ€™m glad I had this journey. I learned a lot of web stuff that has made me a better developer and Iâ€™ve also learned when to be pragmatic. Iâ€™m glad I can help him get his stuff out there and I can still provide technical assistance.Â

items.title: Introduction
items.content_html:
Hi, Iâ€™m Nick.

Iâ€™m a software engineer living in Saint Louis, Missouri. Iâ€™ve been working in the web space, writing .NET and JavaScript apps for about five years. Iâ€™m very interested in iOS and macOS development so thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ll be talking about and posting here.

I started a blog at nickkaczmarek.com, but Iâ€™ll be slowly moving over here. I only have two or three posts there so that shouldnâ€™t be tough.

I hope you all enjoy!
